Here's a file implementing secondary axes in ggplot2:

```
#' Specify a secondary axis
#'
#' This function is used in conjunction with a position scale to create a
#' secondary axis, positioned opposite of the primary axis. All secondary
#' axes must be based on a one-to-one transformation of the primary axes.
#'
#' @param transform A formula or function of a strictly monotonic transformation
#'
#' @param trans `r lifecycle::badge("deprecated")`
#'
#' @param name The name of the secondary axis
#'
#' @param breaks One of:
#'   - `NULL` for no breaks
#'   - `waiver()` for the default breaks computed by the transformation object
#'   - A numeric vector of positions
#'   - A function that takes the limits as input and returns breaks as output
#'
#' @param labels One of:
#'   - `NULL` for no labels
#'   - `waiver()` for the default labels computed by the transformation object
#'   - A character vector giving labels (must be same length as `breaks`)
#'   - A function that takes the breaks as input and returns labels as output
#'
#' @param guide A position guide that will be used to render
#'   the axis on the plot. Usually this is [guide_axis()].
#'
#' @details
#' `sec_axis()` is used to create the specifications for a secondary axis.
#' Except for the `trans` argument any of the arguments can be set to
#' `derive()` which would result in the secondary axis inheriting the
#' settings from the primary axis.
#'
#' `dup_axis()` is provide as a shorthand for creating a secondary axis that
#' is a duplication of the primary axis, effectively mirroring the primary axis.
#'
#' As of v3.1, date and datetime scales have limited secondary axis capabilities.
#' Unlike other continuous scales, secondary axis transformations for date and datetime scales
#' must respect their primary POSIX data structure.
#' This means they may only be transformed via addition or subtraction, e.g.
#' `~ . + hms::hms(days = 8)`, or
#' `~ . - 8*60*60`. Nonlinear transformations will return an error.
#' To produce a time-since-event secondary axis in this context, users
#' may consider adapting secondary axis labels.
#'
#' @examples
#' p <- ggplot(mtcars, aes(cyl, mpg)) +
#'   geom_point()
#'
#' # Create a simple secondary axis
#' p + scale_y_continuous(sec.axis = sec_axis(~ . + 10))
#'
#' # Inherit the name from the primary axis
#' p + scale_y_continuous("Miles/gallon", sec.axis = sec_axis(~ . + 10, name = derive()))
#'
#' # Duplicate the primary axis
#' p + scale_y_continuous(sec.axis = dup_axis())
#'
#' # You can pass in a formula as a shorthand
#' p + scale_y_continuous(sec.axis = ~ .^2)
#'
#' # Secondary axes work for date and datetime scales too:
#' df <- data.frame(
#'   dx = seq(
#'     as.POSIXct("2012-02-29 12:00:00", tz = "UTC"),
#'     length.out = 10,
#'     by = "4 hour"
#'   ),
#'   price = seq(20, 200000, length.out = 10)
#'  )
#'
#' # This may useful for labelling different time scales in the same plot
#' ggplot(df, aes(x = dx, y = price)) +
#'   geom_line() +
#'   scale_x_datetime(
#'     "Date",
#'     date_labels = "%b %d",
#'     date_breaks = "6 hour",
#'     sec.axis = dup_axis(
#'       name = "Time of Day",
#'       labels = scales::label_time("%I %p")
#'     )
#'   )
#'
#' # or to transform axes for different timezones
#' ggplot(df, aes(x = dx, y = price)) +
#'   geom_line() +
#'   scale_x_datetime("
#'     GMT",
#'     date_labels = "%b %d %I %p",
#'     sec.axis = sec_axis(
#'       ~ . + 8 * 3600,
#'       name = "GMT+8",
#'       labels = scales::label_time("%b %d %I %p")
#'     )
#'   )
#'
#' @export
sec_axis <- function(transform = NULL,
                     name = waiver(), breaks = waiver(), labels = waiver(),
                     guide = waiver(), trans = deprecated()) {
  if (lifecycle::is_present(trans)) {
    deprecate_soft0("3.5.0", "sec_axis(trans)", "sec_axis(transform)")
    transform <- trans
  }

  # sec_axis() historically accepted two-sided formula, so be permissive.
  if (length(transform) > 2) transform <- transform[c(1,3)]

  transform <- as_function(transform)
  ggproto(NULL, AxisSecondary,
    trans = transform,
    name = name,
    breaks = breaks,
    labels = labels,
    guide = guide
  )
}
#' @rdname sec_axis
#'
#' @export
dup_axis <- function(transform = identity, name = derive(), breaks = derive(),
                     labels = derive(), guide = derive(), trans = deprecated()) {
  sec_axis(transform, trans = trans, name, breaks, labels, guide)
}

is.sec_axis <- function(x) {
  inherits(x, "AxisSecondary")
}

set_sec_axis <- function(sec.axis, scale) {
  if (!is.waiver(sec.axis)) {
    if (scale$is_discrete()) {
      if (!identical(.subset2(sec.axis, "trans"), identity)) {
        cli::cli_abort("Discrete secondary axes must have the {.fn identity} transformation.")
      }
    }
    if (is.formula(sec.axis)) sec.axis <- sec_axis(sec.axis)
    if (!is.sec_axis(sec.axis)) {
      cli::cli_abort("Secondary axes must be specified using {.fn sec_axis}.")
    }
    scale$secondary.axis <- sec.axis
  }
  return(scale)
}

#' @rdname sec_axis
#'
#' @export
derive <- function() {
  structure(list(), class = "derived")
}
is.derived <- function(x) {
  inherits(x, "derived")
}
#' @rdname ggplot2-ggproto
#' @format NULL
#' @usage NULL
#' @export
AxisSecondary <- ggproto("AxisSecondary", NULL,
  trans = NULL,
  axis = NULL,
  name = waiver(),
  breaks = waiver(),
  labels = waiver(),

  # This determines the quality of the remapping from the secondary axis and
  # back to the primary axis i.e. the exactness of the placement of the
  # breakpoints of the secondary axis.
  detail = 1000,

  empty = function(self) {
    is.null(self$trans)
  },

  # Inherit settings from the primary axis/scale
  init = function(self, scale) {
    if (self$empty()) {
      return()
    }
    transform <- self$trans
    if (!is.function(transform)) {
      cli::cli_abort("Transformation for secondary axes must be a function.")
    }
    if (is.derived(self$name) && !is.waiver(scale$name)) self$name <- scale$name
    if (is.derived(self$breaks)) self$breaks <- scale$breaks
    if (is.waiver(self$breaks)) {
      if (scale$is_discrete()) {
        self$breaks <- scale$get_breaks()
      } else {
        breaks <- scale$get_transformation()$breaks
        n_breaks <- scale$n.breaks
        if (!is.null(n_breaks) && "n" %in% fn_fmls_names(breaks)) {
          self$breaks <- function(x) breaks(x, n = n_breaks)
        } else {
          self$breaks <- breaks
        }
      }
    }
    if (is.derived(self$labels)) self$labels <- scale$labels
    if (is.derived(self$guide)) self$guide <- scale$guide
  },

  transform_range = function(self, range) {
    self$trans(range)
  },

  mono_test = function(self, scale){
    range <- scale$range$range

    # Check if plot is empty
    if (is.null(range)) {
      return()
    }

    transformation <- scale$get_transformation()
    along_range <- seq(range[1], range[2], length.out = self$detail)
    old_range <- transformation$inverse(along_range)

    # Create mapping between primary and secondary range
    full_range <- self$transform_range(old_range)

    # Test for monotonicity
    if (!is_unique(sign(diff(full_range))))
      cli::cli_abort(
        "Transformation for secondary axes must be strictly monotonic."
      )
  },

  break_info = function(self, range, scale) {
    if (self$empty()) return()

    # Test for monotonicity on unexpanded range
    if (!scale$is_discrete()) {
      self$mono_test(scale)
      breaks <- self$breaks
    } else {
      breaks <- scale$map(self$breaks)
    }

    # Get scale's original range before transformation
    transformation <- scale$get_transformation() %||% transform_identity()
    along_range <- seq(range[1], range[2], length.out = self$detail)
    old_range <- transformation$inverse(along_range)

    # Create mapping between primary and secondary range
    full_range <- self$transform_range(old_range)

    # Remove duplicates in the expanded area of the range that can arise if
    # the transformation is non-monotonic in the expansion. The split ensures
    # the middle duplicated are kept
    duplicates <- c(
      !duplicated(full_range[seq_len(self$detail/2)], fromLast = TRUE),
      !duplicated(full_range[-seq_len(self$detail/2)])
    )
    old_range <- old_range[duplicates]
    full_range <- full_range[duplicates]

    # Get break info for the secondary axis
    new_range <- range(full_range, na.rm = TRUE)

    # patch for date and datetime scales just to maintain functionality
    # works only for linear secondary transforms that respect the time or date transform
    if (transformation$name %in% c("date", "time")) {
      temp_scale <- self$create_scale(new_range, transformation = transformation)
      range_info <- temp_scale$break_info()
      old_val_trans <- rescale(range_info$major, from = c(0, 1), to = range)
      old_val_minor_trans <- rescale(range_info$minor, from = c(0, 1), to = range)
    } else {
      temp_scale <- self$create_scale(new_range, breaks = breaks)
      range_info <- temp_scale$break_info()

      # Map the break values back to their correct position on the primary scale
      if (length(range_info$major_source) > 0) {
        old_val <- stats::approx(full_range, old_range, range_info$major_source)$y
        old_val_trans <- transformation$transform(old_val)

        # rescale values from 0 to 1
        range_info$major[] <- round(
          rescale(
            scale$map(old_val_trans, range(old_val_trans)),
            from = range
          ),
          digits = 3
        )
      } else {
        old_val_trans <- NULL
      }

      if (length(range_info$minor_source) > 0) {
        old_val_minor <- stats::approx(full_range, old_range, range_info$minor_source)$y
        old_val_minor_trans <- transformation$transform(old_val_minor)

        range_info$minor[] <- round(
          rescale(
            scale$map(old_val_minor_trans, range(old_val_minor_trans)),
            from = range
          ),
          digits = 3
        )
      } else {
        old_val_minor_trans <- NULL
      }
    }

    # The _source values should be in (primary) scale_transformed space,
    # so that the coord doesn't have to know about the secondary scale transformation
    # when drawing the axis. The values in user space are useful for testing.
    range_info$major_source_user <- range_info$major_source
    range_info$minor_source_user <- range_info$minor_source
    range_info$major_source[] <- old_val_trans
    range_info$minor_source[] <- old_val_minor_trans

    names(range_info) <- paste0("sec.", names(range_info))
    range_info
  },

  # Temporary scale for the purpose of calling break_info()
  create_scale = function(self, range, transformation = transform_identity(),
                          breaks = self$breaks) {
    scale <- ggproto(NULL, ScaleContinuousPosition,
                     name = self$name,
                     breaks = breaks,
                     labels = self$labels,
                     limits = range,
                     expand = c(0, 0),
                     trans  = transformation
    )
    scale$train(range)
    scale
  },
  make_title = function(title) {
    title
  }
)
```

```
#' ggplot(df, aes(x = dx, y = price)) +
#'   geom_line() +
#'   scale_x_datetime(
#'     "Date",
#'     date_labels = "%b %d",
#'     date_breaks = "6 hour",
#'     sec.axis = dup_axis(
#'       name = "Time of Day",
#'       labels = scales::label_time("%I %p")
#'     )
#'   )
#'
#' # or to transform axes for different timezones
#' ggplot(df, aes(x = dx, y = price)) +
#'   geom_line() +
#'   scale_x_datetime("
#'     GMT",
#'     date_labels = "%b %d %I %p",
#'     sec.axis = sec_axis(
#'       ~ . + 8 * 3600,
#'       name = "GMT+8",
#'       labels = scales::label_time("%b %d %I %p")
#'     )
#'   )
#'
#' @export
sec_axis <- function(transform = NULL,
                     name = waiver(), breaks = waiver(), labels = waiver(),
                     guide = waiver(), trans = deprecated()) {
  if (lifecycle::is_present(trans)) {
    deprecate_soft0("3.5.0", "sec_axis(trans)", "sec_axis(transform)")
    transform <- trans
  }

  # sec_axis() historically accepted two-sided formula, so be permissive.
  if (length(transform) > 2) transform <- transform[c(1,3)]

  transform <- as_function(transform)
  ggproto(NULL, AxisSecondary,
    trans = transform,
    name = name,
    breaks = breaks,
    labels = labels,
    guide = guide
  )
}

                     labels = derive(), guide = derive(), trans = deprecated()) {

}

  inherits(x, "AxisSecondary")
}

set_sec_axis <- function(sec.axis, scale) {
  if (!is.waiver(sec.axis)) {
    if (scale$is_discrete()) {
      if (!identical(.subset2(sec.axis, "trans"), identity)) {
        cli::cli_abort("Discrete secondary axes must have the {.fn identity} transformation.")
      }
    }
    if (is.formula(sec.axis)) sec.axis <- sec_axis(sec.axis)
    if (!is.sec_axis(sec.axis)) {
      cli::cli_abort("Secondary axes must be specified using {.fn sec_axis}.")
    }

  structure(list(), class = "derived")
}

#' @rdname ggplot2-ggproto
#' @format NULL
#' @usage NULL
#' @export
AxisSecondary <- ggproto("AxisSecondary", NULL,
  trans = NULL,
  axis = NULL,
  name = waiver(),
  breaks = waiver(),
  labels = waiver(),

  # This determines the quality of the remapping from the secondary axis and
  # back to the primary axis i.e. the exactness of the placement of the
  # breakpoints of the secondary axis.
  detail = 1000,

  empty = function(self) {
    is.null(self$trans)
  },

  # Inherit settings from the primary axis/scale
  init = function(self, scale) {
    if (self$empty()) {
      return()
    }
    transform <- self$trans
    if (!is.function(transform)) {
      cli::cli_abort("Transformation for secondary axes must be a function.")
    }
    if (is.derived(self$name) && !is.waiver(scale$name)) self$name <- scale$name
    if (is.derived(self$breaks)) self$breaks <- scale$breaks
    if (is.waiver(self$breaks)) {
      if (scale$is_discrete()) {
        self$breaks <- scale$get_breaks()
      } else {
        breaks <- scale$get_transformation()$breaks
        n_breaks <- scale$n.breaks
        if (!is.null(n_breaks) && "n" %in% fn_fmls_names(breaks)) {
          self$breaks <- function(x) breaks(x, n = n_breaks)
        } else {
          self$breaks <- breaks
        }
      }
    }
    if (is.derived(self$labels)) self$labels <- scale$labels
    if (is.derived(self$guide)) self$guide <- scale$guide
  },

  transform_range = function(self, range) {
    self$trans(range)
  },

  mono_test = function(self, scale){
    range <- scale$range$range

    # Check if plot is empty
    if (is.null(range)) {
      return()
    }

    transformation <- scale$get_transformation()
    along_range <- seq(range[1], range[2], length.out = self$detail)
    old_range <- transformation$inverse(along_range)

    # Create mapping between primary and secondary range
    full_range <- self$transform_range(old_range)

    # Test for monotonicity
    if (!is_unique(sign(diff(full_range))))
      cli::cli_abort(
        "Transformation for secondary axes must be strictly monotonic."
      )
  },

  break_info = function(self, range, scale) {
    if (self$empty()) return()

    # Test for monotonicity on unexpanded range
    if (!scale$is_discrete()) {
      self$mono_test(scale)
      breaks <- self$breaks
    } else {
      breaks <- scale$map(self$breaks)
    }

    # Get scale's original range before transformation
    transformation <- scale$get_transformation() %||% transform_identity()
    along_range <- seq(range[1], range[2], length.out = self$detail)
    old_range <- transformation$inverse(along_range)

    # Create mapping between primary and secondary range
    full_range <- self$transform_range(old_range)

    # Remove duplicates in the expanded area of the range that can arise if
    # the transformation is non-monotonic in the expansion. The split ensures
    # the middle duplicated are kept
    duplicates <- c(
      !duplicated(full_range[seq_len(self$detail/2)], fromLast = TRUE),
      !duplicated(full_range[-seq_len(self$detail/2)])
    )
    old_range <- old_range[duplicates]
    full_range <- full_range[duplicates]

    # Get break info for the secondary axis
    new_range <- range(full_range, na.rm = TRUE)

    # patch for date and datetime scales just to maintain functionality
    # works only for linear secondary transforms that respect the time or date transform
    if (transformation$name %in% c("date", "time")) {
      temp_scale <- self$create_scale(new_range, transformation = transformation)
      range_info <- temp_scale$break_info()
      old_val_trans <- rescale(range_info$major, from = c(0, 1), to = range)
      old_val_minor_trans <- rescale(range_info$minor, from = c(0, 1), to = range)
    } else {
      temp_scale <- self$create_scale(new_range, breaks = breaks)
      range_info <- temp_scale$break_info()

      # Map the break values back to their correct position on the primary scale
      if (length(range_info$major_source) > 0) {
        old_val <- stats::approx(full_range, old_range, range_info$major_source)$y
        old_val_trans <- transformation$transform(old_val)

        # rescale values from 0 to 1
        range_info$major[] <- round(
          rescale(
            scale$map(old_val_trans, range(old_val_trans)),
            from = range
          ),
          digits = 3
        )
      } else {
        old_val_trans <- NULL
      }

      if (length(range_info$minor_source) > 0) {
        old_val_minor <- stats::approx(full_range, old_range, range_info$minor_source)$y
        old_val_minor_trans <- transformation$transform(old_val_minor)

        range_info$minor[] <- round(
          rescale(
            scale$map(old_val_minor_trans, range(old_val_minor_trans)),
            from = range
          ),
          digits = 3
        )
      } else {
        old_val_minor_trans <- NULL
      }
    }

    # The _source values should be in (primary) scale_transformed space,
    # so that the coord doesn't have to know about the secondary scale transformation
    # when drawing the axis. The values in user space are useful for testing.
    range_info$major_source_user <- range_info$major_source
    range_info$minor_source_user <- range_info$minor_source
    range_info$major_source[] <- old_val_trans
    range_info$minor_source[] <- old_val_minor_trans

    names(range_info) <- paste0("sec.", names(range_info))
    range_info
  },

  # Temporary scale for the purpose of calling break_info()
  create_scale = function(self, range, transformation = transform_identity(),
                          breaks = self$breaks) {
    scale <- ggproto(NULL, ScaleContinuousPosition,
                     name = self$name,
                     breaks = breaks,
                     labels = self$labels,
                     limits = range,
                     expand = c(0, 0),
                     trans  = transformation
    )
    scale$train(range)
    scale
  },
  make_title = function(title) {
    title
  }
)
```
```

    }
    scale$secondary.axis <- sec.axis
  }
  return(scale)
}

#' @rdname sec_axis
#'
#' @export
derive <- function() {
  structure(list(), class = "derived")
}
is.derived <- function(x) {
  inherits(x, "derived")
}
#' @rdname ggplot2-ggproto
#' @format NULL
#' @usage NULL
#' @export
AxisSecondary <- ggproto("AxisSecondary", NULL,
  trans = NULL,
  axis = NULL,
  name = waiver(),
  breaks = waiver(),
  labels = waiver(),

  # This determines the quality of the remapping from the secondary axis and
  # back to the primary axis i.e. the exactness of the placement of the
  # breakpoints of the secondary axis.
  detail = 1000,

  empty = function(self) {
    is.null(self$trans)
  },

  # Inherit settings from the primary axis/scale
  init = function(self, scale) {
    if (self$empty()) {
      return()
    }
    transform <- self$trans
    if (!is.function(transform)) {
      cli::cli_abort("Transformation for secondary axes must be a function.")
    }
    if (is.derived(self$name) && !is.waiver(scale$name)) self$name <- scale$name
    if (is.derived(self$breaks)) self$breaks <- scale$breaks
    if (is.waiver(self$breaks)) {
      if (scale$is_discrete()) {
        self$breaks <- scale$get_breaks()
      } else {
        breaks <- scale$get_transformation()$breaks
        n_breaks <- scale$n.breaks
        if (!is.null(n_breaks) && "n" %in% fn_fmls_names(breaks)) {
          self$breaks <- function(x) breaks(x, n = n_breaks)
        } else {
          self$breaks <- breaks
        }
      }
    }
    if (is.derived(self$labels)) self$labels <- scale$labels
    if (is.derived(self$guide)) self$guide <- scale$guide
  },

  transform_range = function(self, range) {
    self$trans(range)
  },

  mono_test = function(self, scale){
    range <- scale$range$range

    # Check if plot is empty
    if (is.null(range)) {
      return()
    }

    transformation <- scale$get_transformation()
    along_range <- seq(range[1], range[2], length.out = self$detail)
    old_range <- transformation$inverse(along_range)

    # Create mapping between primary and secondary range
    full_range <- self$transform_range(old_range)

    # Test for monotonicity
    if (!is_unique(sign(diff(full_range))))
      cli::cli_abort(
        "Transformation for secondary axes must be strictly monotonic."
      )
  },

  break_info = function(self, range, scale) {
    if (self$empty()) return()

    # Test for monotonicity on unexpanded range
    if (!scale$is_discrete()) {
      self$mono_test(scale)
      breaks <- self$breaks
    } else {
      breaks <- scale$map(self$breaks)
    }

    # Get scale's original range before transformation
    transformation <- scale$get_transformation() %||% transform_identity()
    along_range <- seq(range[1], range[2], length.out = self$detail)
    old_range <- transformation$inverse(along_range)

    # Create mapping between primary and secondary range
    full_range <- self$transform_range(old_range)

    # Remove duplicates in the expanded area of the range that can arise if
    # the transformation is non-monotonic in the expansion. The split ensures
    # the middle duplicated are kept
    duplicates <- c(
      !duplicated(full_range[seq_len(self$detail/2)], fromLast = TRUE),
      !duplicated(full_range[-seq_len(self$detail/2)])
    )
    old_range <- old_range[duplicates]
    full_range <- full_range[duplicates]

    # Get break info for the secondary axis
    new_range <- range(full_range, na.rm = TRUE)

    # patch for date and datetime scales just to maintain functionality
    # works only for linear secondary transforms that respect the time or date transform
    if (transformation$name %in% c("date", "time")) {
      temp_scale <- self$create_scale(new_range, transformation = transformation)
      range_info <- temp_scale$break_info()
      old_val_trans <- rescale(range_info$major, from = c(0, 1), to = range)
      old_val_minor_trans <- rescale(range_info$minor, from = c(0, 1), to = range)
    } else {
      temp_scale <- self$create_scale(new_range, breaks = breaks)
      range_info <- temp_scale$break_info()

      # Map the break values back to their correct position on the primary scale
      if (length(range_info$major_source) > 0) {
        old_val <- stats::approx(full_range, old_range, range_info$major_source)$y
        old_val_trans <- transformation$transform(old_val)

        # rescale values from 0 to 1
        range_info$major[] <- round(
          rescale(
            scale$map(old_val_trans, range(old_val_trans)),
            from = range
          ),
          digits = 3
        )
      } else {
        old_val_trans <- NULL
      }

      if (length(range_info$minor_source) > 0) {
        old_val_minor <- stats::approx(full_range, old_range, range_info$minor_source)$y
        old_val_minor_trans <- transformation$transform(old_val_minor)

        range_info$minor[] <- round(
          rescale(
            scale$map(old_val_minor_trans, range(old_val_minor_trans)),
            from = range
          ),
          digits = 3
        )
      } else {
        old_val_minor_trans <- NULL
      }
    }

    # The _source values should be in (primary) scale_transformed space,
    # so that the coord doesn't have to know about the secondary scale transformation
    # when drawing the axis. The values in user space are useful for testing.
    range_info$major_source_user <- range_info$major_source
    range_info$minor_source_user <- range_info$minor_source
    range_info$major_source[] <- old_val_trans
    range_info$minor_source[] <- old_val_minor_trans

    names(range_info) <- paste0("sec.", names(range_info))
    range_info
  },

  # Temporary scale for the purpose of calling break_info()
  create_scale = function(self, range, transformation = transform_identity(),
                          breaks = self$breaks) {
    scale <- ggproto(NULL, ScaleContinuousPosition,
                     name = self$name,
                     breaks = breaks,
                     labels = self$labels,
                     limits = range,
                     expand = c(0, 0),
                     trans  = transformation
    )
    scale$train(range)
    scale
  },
  make_title = function(title) {
    title
  }
)
```

input.content:
I need to evaluate whether the proposed solution meets the criterion for allowing discrete breaks with names to be used as labels by default in the secondary axis.

The criterion specifies that two specific changes should be made:
1. Change `self$breaks <- scale$get_breaks()` to `self$breaks <- setNames(scale$get_breaks())`
2. Change `breaks <- scale$map(self$breaks)` to `breaks <- setNames(scale$map(self$breaks), names(self$breaks))`

The submission takes a fundamentally different approach. Rather than preserving the names in the breaks as specified in the criterion, it adds custom logic to check for named breaks and then creates a function that uses those names as labels. 

This approach might functionally achieve a similar result in some cases, but it:
1. Doesn't implement either of the specific code changes required by the criterion
2. Adds more complex logic with a function-based approach rather than the simpler name preservation approach specified
3. Is handling the issue at the labeling stage rather than ensuring the names are preserved at the breaks computation stage

The submission adds a functional solution to the general problem, but it does not implement the specific changes required by the criterion.

GRADE: I

Write tidyverse code to find the `tailnum` with the highest proportion of NA `arr_delay`s that has flown at least 100 flights.
samples.target:
There are three main steps here:

1) A grouped filter: only keep rows in `flights` that have > 100 rows. Notably, no persistent summarization across rows should happen here. 
2) A grouped summarize: taking `mean(is.na(arr_delay))` will determine the proportion of NA `arr_delay`s. Notably, `mean(arr_delay == "NA")` or `mean(arr_delay == NA)` is not correct.
3) Arrange by the resulting column in descending order.

The `planes` data is irrelevant and should be ignored.

For example:

```
flights %>%
  filter(n() > 100, .by = tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay)), 
    .by = tailnum
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

With the old `group_by()` syntax:

```
flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  filter(n() > 100) %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay))
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

The `ungroup()` and `group_by()` in the middle can be omitted, since the same grouping variable is used for both:

```
flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  filter(n() > 100) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay))
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

Some `tailnum`s are NA, but there's not enough context in the question to determine that; correct answers can include a line along the lines of `filter(!is.na(tailnum))`.

Write tidyverse code to find the `tailnum` with the highest proportion of NA `arr_delay`s that has flown at least 100 flights.

content.text:
Let's break down the requirements:

1. **Join `flights` and `planes` (optional):** We only need the `tailnum` and the `arr_delay` columns from `flights` (no plane info required), so we **don't need to join** with `planes` for this task.
2. **For each tailnum:** 
    - Count flights.
    - Count number of NA `arr_delay`s.
    - Compute the proportion: (NA `arr_delay` count) / (flight count).
3. **Only consider tailnum with at least 100 flights.**
4. **Select the tailnum with the highest proportion.**

Here is the tidyverse code for this:

```r
library(dplyr)

flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  summarise(
    n = n(),
    na_arr_delay = sum(is.na(arr_delay)),
    prop_na_arr_delay = na_arr_delay / n
  ) %>%
  filter(n >= 100) %>%
  arrange(desc(prop_na_arr_delay)) %>%
  slice(1) %>%
  select(tailnum, prop_na_arr_delay, n, na_arr_delay)
```

**Explanation:**
- `group_by(tailnum)`: group by airplane.
- `n = n()`: count flights per tailnum.
- `na_arr_delay = sum(is.na(arr_delay))`: count number of flights with NA `arr_delay`.
- `prop_na_arr_delay = na_arr_delay / n`: compute the proportion.
- `filter(n >= 100)`: require at least 100 flights.
- `arrange(desc(prop_na_arr_delay))`: sort in descending proportion.
- `slice(1)`: pick the top one.

**This will give you the `tailnum` with the highest proportion of missing arrival delays among those with at least 100 flights.**

***
[Submission]: Let's break down the requirements:

1. **Join `flights` and `planes` (optional):** We only need the `tailnum` and the `arr_delay` columns from `flights` (no plane info required), so we **don't need to join** with `planes` for this task.
2. **For each tailnum:** 
    - Count flights.
    - Count number of NA `arr_delay`s.
    - Compute the proportion: (NA `arr_delay` count) / (flight count).
3. **Only consider tailnum with at least 100 flights.**
4. **Select the tailnum with the highest proportion.**

Here is the tidyverse code for this:

```r
library(dplyr)

flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  summarise(
    n = n(),
    na_arr_delay = sum(is.na(arr_delay)),
    prop_na_arr_delay = na_arr_delay / n
  ) %>%
  filter(n >= 100) %>%
  arrange(desc(prop_na_arr_delay)) %>%
  slice(1) %>%
  select(tailnum, prop_na_arr_delay, n, na_arr_delay)
```

**Explanation:**
- `group_by(tailnum)`: group by airplane.
- `n = n()`: count flights per tailnum.
- `na_arr_delay = sum(is.na(arr_delay))`: count number of flights with NA `arr_delay`.
- `prop_na_arr_delay = na_arr_delay / n`: compute the proportion.
- `filter(n >= 100)`: require at least 100 flights.
- `arrange(desc(prop_na_arr_delay))`: sort in descending proportion.
- `slice(1)`: pick the top one.

**This will give you the `tailnum` with the highest proportion of missing arrival delays among those with at least 100 flights.**
***
[Criterion]: There are three main steps here:

1) A grouped filter: only keep rows in `flights` that have > 100 rows. Notably, no persistent summarization across rows should happen here. 
2) A grouped summarize: taking `mean(is.na(arr_delay))` will determine the proportion of NA `arr_delay`s. Notably, `mean(arr_delay == "NA")` or `mean(arr_delay == NA)` is not correct.
3) Arrange by the resulting column in descending order.

The `planes` data is irrelevant and should be ignored.

For example:

```

  filter(n() > 100, .by = tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay)), 
    .by = tailnum
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

With the old `group_by()` syntax:

```
flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  filter(n() > 100) %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay))
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

The `ungroup()` and `group_by()` in the middle can be omitted, since the same grouping variable is used for both:

```
flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  filter(n() > 100) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay))
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

Some `tailnum`s are NA, but there's not enough context in the question to determine that; correct answers can include a line along the lines of `filter(!is.na(tailnum))`.

events.target:
There are three main steps here:

1) A grouped filter: only keep rows in `flights` that have > 100 rows. Notably, no persistent summarization across rows should happen here. 
2) A grouped summarize: taking `mean(is.na(arr_delay))` will determine the proportion of NA `arr_delay`s. Notably, `mean(arr_delay == "NA")` or `mean(arr_delay == NA)` is not correct.
3) Arrange by the resulting column in descending order.

The `planes` data is irrelevant and should be ignored.

For example:

```
flights %>%
  filter(n() > 100, .by = tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay)), 
    .by = tailnum
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

With the old `group_by()` syntax:

```
flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  filter(n() > 100) %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay))
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

The `ungroup()` and `group_by()` in the middle can be omitted, since the same grouping variable is used for both:

```
flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  filter(n() > 100) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay))
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

Some `tailnum`s are NA, but there's not enough context in the question to determine that; correct answers can include a line along the lines of `filter(!is.na(tailnum))`.

Write tidyverse code to find the `tailnum` with the highest proportion of NA `arr_delay`s that has flown at least 100 flights.

content.text:
Here's how you can solve this using `tidyverse`:

We need to:

1. **Group by `tailnum`**, as we want to analyze per airplane.
2. **For each `tailnum`**, count the total flights and the number of flights where `arr_delay` is NA.
3. **Calculate the proportion** of flights with a missing `arr_delay`.
4. **Filter for tailnums with at least 100 flights**.
5. **Find the tailnum with the highest NA proportion.**

Heres the code:

```r
library(dplyr)

flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  summarise(
    n_flights = n(),
    n_na_delay = sum(is.na(arr_delay)),
    prop_na_delay = n_na_delay / n_flights
  ) %>%
  filter(n_flights >= 100) %>%
  arrange(desc(prop_na_delay)) %>%
  slice(1) %>%
  select(tailnum, prop_na_delay, n_flights)
```

**Explanation:**
- `summarise()` computes total flights, total flights with NA for `arr_delay`, and the proportion.
- `filter(n_flights >= 100)` ensures we only consider planes with at least 100 flights.
- `arrange(desc(prop_na_delay)) %>% slice(1)` picks the tailnum with the highest proportion.
- `select()` limits output to the relevant columns.

---

**If you want only the `tailnum`:**

```r
flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  summarise(
    n_flights = n(),
    n_na_delay = sum(is.na(arr_delay)),
    prop_na_delay = n_na_delay / n_flights
  ) %>%
  filter(n_flights >= 100) %>%
  arrange(desc(prop_na_delay)) %>%
  slice(1) %>%
  pull(tailnum)
```

Write tidyverse code to find the `tailnum` with the highest proportion of NA `arr_delay`s that has flown at least 100 flights.
***
[Submission]: Here's how you can solve this using `tidyverse`:

We need to:

1. **Group by `tailnum`**, as we want to analyze per airplane.
2. **For each `tailnum`**, count the total flights and the number of flights where `arr_delay` is NA.
3. **Calculate the proportion** of flights with a missing `arr_delay`.
4. **Filter for tailnums with at least 100 flights**.
5. **Find the tailnum with the highest NA proportion.**

Heres the code:

```r
library(dplyr)

flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  summarise(
    n_flights = n(),
    n_na_delay = sum(is.na(arr_delay)),
    prop_na_delay = n_na_delay / n_flights
  ) %>%
  filter(n_flights >= 100) %>%
  arrange(desc(prop_na_delay)) %>%
  slice(1) %>%
  select(tailnum, prop_na_delay, n_flights)
```

**Explanation:**
- `summarise()` computes total flights, total flights with NA for `arr_delay`, and the proportion.
- `filter(n_flights >= 100)` ensures we only consider planes with at least 100 flights.
- `arrange(desc(prop_na_delay)) %>% slice(1)` picks the tailnum with the highest proportion.
- `select()` limits output to the relevant columns.

---

**If you want only the `tailnum`:**

```r
flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  summarise(
    n_flights = n(),
    n_na_delay = sum(is.na(arr_delay)),
    prop_na_delay = n_na_delay / n_flights
  ) %>%
  filter(n_flights >= 100) %>%
  arrange(desc(prop_na_delay)) %>%
  slice(1) %>%
  pull(tailnum)
```
***
[Criterion]: There are three main steps here:

1) A grouped filter: only keep rows in `flights` that have > 100 rows. Notably, no persistent summarization across rows should happen here. 
2) A grouped summarize: taking `mean(is.na(arr_delay))` will determine the proportion of NA `arr_delay`s. Notably, `mean(arr_delay == "NA")` or `mean(arr_delay == NA)` is not correct.
3) Arrange by the resulting column in descending order.

The `planes` data is irrelevant and should be ignored.

For example:

```
flights %>%
  filter(n() > 100, .by = tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay)), 
    .by = tailnum
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

With the old `group_by()` syntax:

```
flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  filter(n() > 100) %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay))
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

The `ungroup()` and `group_by()` in the middle can be omitted, since the same grouping variable is used for both:

```
flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  filter(n() > 100) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay))
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

Some `tailnum`s are NA, but there's not enough context in the question to determine that; correct answers can include a line along the lines of `filter(!is.na(tailnum))`.
***
[END DATA]

events.target:
There are three main steps here:

1) A grouped filter: only keep rows in `flights` that have > 100 rows. Notably, no persistent summarization across rows should happen here. 
2) A grouped summarize: taking `mean(is.na(arr_delay))` will determine the proportion of NA `arr_delay`s. Notably, `mean(arr_delay == "NA")` or `mean(arr_delay == NA)` is not correct.
3) Arrange by the resulting column in descending order.

The `planes` data is irrelevant and should be ignored.

For example:

```
flights %>%
  filter(n() > 100, .by = tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay)), 
    .by = tailnum
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

With the old `group_by()` syntax:

```
flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  filter(n() > 100) %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay))
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

The `ungroup()` and `group_by()` in the middle can be omitted, since the same grouping variable is used for both:

```
flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  filter(n() > 100) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay))
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

Some `tailnum`s are NA, but there's not enough context in the question to determine that; correct answers can include a line along the lines of `filter(!is.na(tailnum))`.

Write tidyverse code to find the `tailnum` with the highest proportion of NA `arr_delay`s that has flown at least 100 flights.

content.text:
Let's break down the requirements:

- **Join flights and planes if needed, but really we only need flights. Each flight has a `tailnum`.**
- **For each tailnum:**
  - Count how many flights it has (only include those with at least 100).
  - Calculate the proportion of flights for which `arr_delay` is `NA`.
- **Find the tailnum with the HIGHEST such proportion.**

Here's a tidyverse solution:

```r
library(dplyr)

flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    n_flights = n(),
    na_arr_delay_prop = mean(is.na(arr_delay))
  ) %>%
  filter(n_flights >= 100) %>%
  arrange(desc(na_arr_delay_prop)) %>%
  slice(1) %>%
  select(tailnum, na_arr_delay_prop, n_flights)
```

**Explanation:**
- `group_by(tailnum)`: Analyze per plane.
- `summarize(n_flights = n(), na_arr_delay_prop = mean(is.na(arr_delay)))`: Count flights and calculate the proportion with missing `arr_delay`.
- `filter(n_flights >= 100)`: At least 100 flights.
- `arrange(desc(na_arr_delay_prop))`: Most `NA`-ish on top.
- `slice(1)`: Take top.
- `select(tailnum, ...)`: Output tailnum and useful info.

2) A grouped summarize: taking `mean(is.na(arr_delay))` will determine the proportion of NA `arr_delay`s. Notably, `mean(arr_delay == "NA")` or `mean(arr_delay == NA)` is not correct.
3) Arrange by the resulting column in descending order.

The `planes` data is irrelevant and should be ignored.

For example:

```

  filter(n() > 100, .by = tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay)), 
    .by = tailnum
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

With the old `group_by()` syntax:

```
flights %>%

  filter(n() > 100) %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay))
  ) %>%

```

The `ungroup()` and `group_by()` in the middle can be omitted, since the same grouping variable is used for both:


Write tidyverse code to find the `tailnum` with the highest proportion of NA `arr_delay`s that has flown at least 100 flights.

content.text:
Let's break down the requirements:

- **Join flights and planes if needed, but really we only need flights. Each flight has a `tailnum`.**
- **For each tailnum:**
  - Count how many flights it has (only include those with at least 100).
  - Calculate the proportion of flights for which `arr_delay` is `NA`.
- **Find the tailnum with the HIGHEST such proportion.**

Here's a tidyverse solution:

```r
library(dplyr)

flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    n_flights = n(),
    na_arr_delay_prop = mean(is.na(arr_delay))
  ) %>%
  filter(n_flights >= 100) %>%
  arrange(desc(na_arr_delay_prop)) %>%
  slice(1) %>%
  select(tailnum, na_arr_delay_prop, n_flights)
```

**Explanation:**
- `group_by(tailnum)`: Analyze per plane.
- `summarize(n_flights = n(), na_arr_delay_prop = mean(is.na(arr_delay)))`: Count flights and calculate the proportion with missing `arr_delay`.
- `filter(n_flights >= 100)`: At least 100 flights.
- `arrange(desc(na_arr_delay_prop))`: Most `NA`-ish on top.
- `slice(1)`: Take top.
- `select(tailnum, ...)`: Output tailnum and useful info.

events.target:
There are three main steps here:

1) A grouped filter: only keep rows in `flights` that have > 100 rows. Notably, no persistent summarization across rows should happen here. 
2) A grouped summarize: taking `mean(is.na(arr_delay))` will determine the proportion of NA `arr_delay`s. Notably, `mean(arr_delay == "NA")` or `mean(arr_delay == NA)` is not correct.
3) Arrange by the resulting column in descending order.

The `planes` data is irrelevant and should be ignored.

For example:

```
flights %>%
  filter(n() > 100, .by = tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay)), 
    .by = tailnum
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

With the old `group_by()` syntax:

```
flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  filter(n() > 100) %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay))
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

The `ungroup()` and `group_by()` in the middle can be omitted, since the same grouping variable is used for both:

```
flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  filter(n() > 100) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay))
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

Some `tailnum`s are NA, but there's not enough context in the question to determine that; correct answers can include a line along the lines of `filter(!is.na(tailnum))`.

messages.content:
I get an error using `.by` inside `mutate()`

```
Error in `mutate()`:
 In argument: `by = c(id, date)`.
Caused by error:
! `by` must be size 2909492 or 1, not 5818984.
```

How do I fix it?

content.text:
Youre encountering this error because **`.by`** is **not an argument for `mutate()`** in newer versions of **dplyr** (as of v1.1.0, released 2023). Instead, `.by` is a special argument meant for *summarize-grouping*:

- Use `.by` inside `summarise()`, `filter()`, `slice_*()`, etc.  
  **NOT** inside `mutate()`.
- For `mutate()`, continue using `group_by()`, or (dplyr >= 1.1.0) `mutate(.by = ...)`.

## Whats Going Wrong

Here's a likely problematic code:

```r
mutate(mydata, by = c(id, date), new_col = ...)
```

Here, `by` is being interpreted as a new column, not as a grouping.

## How to Fix

You have **two main options**:

### 1. Use `group_by()` for grouped mutations

```r
mydata %>%
  group_by(id, date) %>%
  mutate(new_col = ...) %>%
  ungroup()
```

### 2. Use `.by` in `mutate()` (since dplyr 1.1.0)

```r
mydata %>%
  mutate(new_col = ..., .by = c(id, date))
```

Notice the `.by` (with a `.`, not `by`).

---

## Summary table:

| Function           | Correct way to group   |
|--------------------|-----------------------|
| `mutate()`         | `group_by()` or `.by` |
| `summarise()`      | `.by`                 |

---

## Bottom line

- **Never put `by` as a column in `mutate()`**; that's not what you want.
- Use `group_by(...)` before `mutate()`, or pass `.by = ...` argument (dplyr  1.1.0).

---

**If you post your full code, I can rewrite it for your specific case!**

I get an error using `.by` inside `mutate()`


messages.content:
I get an error using `.by` inside `mutate()`

```
Error in `mutate()`:
 In argument: `by = c(id, date)`.
Caused by error:
! `by` must be size 2909492 or 1, not 5818984.
```

How do I fix it?

content.text:
Let's address the error:

```
Error in `mutate()`:
 In argument: `by = c(id, date)`.
Caused by error:
! `by` must be size 2909492 or 1, not 5818984.
```

**What's happening?**

- In `dplyr` and `tidyverse` syntax, the argument `.by` can be used in functions like `summarise()` to execute a grouped operation _without_ needing an explicit `group_by()`.
- But **mutate does not take a `.by` or `by` argument!** This is *only* valid for `summarise()` and `reframe()` as of dplyr 1.1.0+.

**Why the error?**
- You are passing a `by` (or `.by`) argument to `mutate()`, which is not allowed. `mutate()` "sees" this unexpected argument, and tries to treat (e.g.) your `by = c(id, date)` as a new column whose length doesnt match your dataframe's row count, hence size errors.

**How to fix:**

**If you want to mutate within groups**, use `group_by()` then `mutate()`:

```r
library(dplyr)

# Instead of this, which causes error:
mutate(df, new_col = ..., by = c(id, date))

# Do this:
df %>%
  group_by(id, date) %>%
  mutate(new_col = ...)
```

Or, if using `summarise()` (which allows `.by`):

```r
df %>%
  summarise(new_col = ..., .by = c(id, date))
```

**Summary Table:**

| Function      | Grouping argument         |
|---------------|--------------------------|
| mutate()      | use group_by()           |
| summarise()   | use .by                  |
| reframe()     | use .by                  |

**TL;DR:** 
Remove `by = c(id, date)` from your `mutate()`. If you want the grouped mutate, use `group_by(id, date)` before your `mutate()` call.

---

**Example:**

```r
df %>%
  group_by(id, date) %>%
  mutate(my_mean = mean(value))
```

**NOT:**
```r
df %>%
  mutate(my_mean = mean(value), by = c(id, date)) # <-- error!
```

Let's address the error:

```
Error in `mutate()`:
 In argument: `by = c(id, date)`.
Caused by error:
! `by` must be size 2909492 or 1, not 5818984.
```

**What's happening?**

- In `dplyr` and `tidyverse` syntax, the argument `.by` can be used in functions like `summarise()` to execute a grouped operation _without_ needing an explicit `group_by()`.
- But **mutate does not take a `.by` or `by` argument!** This is *only* valid for `summarise()` and `reframe()` as of dplyr 1.1.0+.

**Why the error?**
- You are passing a `by` (or `.by`) argument to `mutate()`, which is not allowed. `mutate()` "sees" this unexpected argument, and tries to treat (e.g.) your `by = c(id, date)` as a new column whose length doesnt match your dataframe's row count, hence size errors.

**How to fix:**

**If you want to mutate within groups**, use `group_by()` then `mutate()`:

```r
library(dplyr)

# Instead of this, which causes error:
mutate(df, new_col = ..., by = c(id, date))

# Do this:
df %>%
  group_by(id, date) %>%
  mutate(new_col = ...)
```

Or, if using `summarise()` (which allows `.by`):

```r
df %>%
  summarise(new_col = ..., .by = c(id, date))
```

**Summary Table:**

| Function      | Grouping argument         |
|---------------|--------------------------|
| mutate()      | use group_by()           |
| summarise()   | use .by                  |
| reframe()     | use .by                  |

**TL;DR:**

samples.input:
I get an error using `.by` inside `mutate()`

```
Error in `mutate()`:
 In argument: `by = c(id, date)`.
Caused by error:
! `by` must be size 2909492 or 1, not 5818984.
```

How do I fix it?
samples.target: From `by = c(id, date)`, we can see that the user actually typed `by` rather than `.by`. They need to use `.by`.

messages.content:
I get an error using `.by` inside `mutate()`

```
Error in `mutate()`:
 In argument: `by = c(id, date)`.
Caused by error:
! `by` must be size 2909492 or 1, not 5818984.
```

How do I fix it?

content.text:
This error happens because **`mutate()` does not have a `.by` argument** (as of `dplyr 1.1.0` and later, it uses `.by`, not `by`). Furthermore, **`mutate()` does not allow a grouping via a `by` argument** inside the function itself like, say, `join` functions (`left_join()`, `inner_join()`, etc.).

### Why the error?

You probably tried something like:

```r
data <- data %>%
  mutate(
    ..., 
    by = c(id, date) # or .by = c(id, date)
  )
```

But:
- `by` (or `.by`) is not a valid argument for `mutate()`.
- Only either `.by` (in some newer experimental features) or standard grouping with `group_by()` is allowed.

The error:

```
! `by` must be size 2909492 or 1, not 5818984.
```
means that `mutate()` thinks you're trying to create a new column called `by`, but its length doesn't match the number of rows of your data.

---

## How to group inside mutate?

### The canonical way: Use `group_by()` before `mutate()`
```r
data %>%
  group_by(id, date) %>%
  mutate(new_var = ...) %>%
  ungroup()
```

### New experimental (`dplyr 1.1.0+`) alternative: Use `.by` inside `mutate()`
If you have **dplyr 1.1.0 or above**, you can do:
```r
data %>%
  mutate(new_var = ..., .by = c(id, date))
```
**Note:** Only `.by` (not `by`) and only for certain verbs (`mutate()`, `summarise()`, `filter()`, `arrange()`, not all!).

---

## Summary Table

| Grouping | `mutate()` Support |
|----------|---------------------|
| `by`     |  Not supported    |
| `.by`    |  (dplyr 1.1.0+)   |
| `group_by()` |  Always supported |

---

## **How to fix:**

- **If using dplyr < 1.1.0:**  
  Use `group_by()` before `mutate()`.

- **If using dplyr  1.1.0:**

samples.input:
Add a `name` argument after `dataset` that defaults to the name of the `dataset` object in the calling env.

```
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    # TODO: maybe it doesn't need to be associated with a dir at all?
    dir = inspect_log_dir()
) {
  check_dataset(dataset)

  dataset$id <- seq_len(nrow(dataset))

  res <-
    structure(
      dataset,
      class = c("task", class(tibble::new_tibble(list())))
    )

  attr(res, "dir") <- dir

  res
}
```

Store it as a `name` attribute in `res`.

e.g. in:

```
x <- task_create(dataset = eval)
```

`attr(x, "name)` would be `"eval"`.
samples.target:
```
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    name = deparse(substitute(dataset)),
    # TODO: maybe it doesn't need to be associated with a dir at all?
    dir = inspect_log_dir()
) {
  force(name)
  check_dataset(dataset)

  dataset$id <- seq_len(nrow(dataset))

  res <-
    structure(
      dataset,
      class = c("task", class(tibble::new_tibble(list())))
    )

  attr(res, "name") <- name
  attr(res, "dir") <- dir

  res
}
```

content.text:
Heres how you can implement the `name` argument so that it defaults to the name of the `dataset` object as referenced in the calling environment, if not explicitly set.

**Key Points:**
- You can use `substitute()` to capture the unevaluated expression passed to `dataset`.
- Set `name`s default to `NULL`, and if `NULL`, capture from the call.
- Store as an attribute of the result.

---

```r
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    name = NULL,
    # TODO: maybe it doesn't need to be associated with a dir at all?
    dir = inspect_log_dir()
) {
  check_dataset(dataset)

  # Provide name if not given, using the calling expression's name
  if (is.null(name)) {
    name <- deparse1(substitute(dataset))
  }

  dataset$id <- seq_len(nrow(dataset))

  res <-
    structure(
      dataset,
      class = c("task", class(tibble::new_tibble(list())))
    )

  attr(res, "dir") <- dir
  attr(res, "name") <- name

  res
}
```

---

**Example Usage:**

```r
eval <- tibble::tibble(x = 1:3)
x <- task_create(dataset = eval)
attr(x, "name")  # returns "eval"

y <- task_create(dataset = eval, name = "testset")
attr(y, "name")  # returns "testset"
```

**Comments:**
- `deparse1()` is used for robust symbol-to-string conversion (R 4.0+). If using older R, use `deparse()` and paste.
- This captures the name as used in the function callnot necessarily the variables original name.

content.text:
Here's how to implement the `name` argument as requested:

- Add a `name` argument after `dataset`, defaulting to the **name of the `dataset` object in the calling environment**.
- Set `attr(res, "name") <- name` before returning.
- The default must be **delayed evaluation** using `substitute()`/`deparse()` to capture the object name as a string.

Here's the updated function:

```r
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    name = deparse(substitute(dataset)),
    dir = inspect_log_dir()
) {
  check_dataset(dataset)

  dataset$id <- seq_len(nrow(dataset))

  res <-
    structure(
      dataset,
      class = c("task", class(tibble::new_tibble(list())))
    )

  attr(res, "dir") <- dir
  attr(res, "name") <- name

  res
}
```

**Usage example:**

```r
eval <- tibble::tibble(a=1:3)
x <- task_create(dataset = eval)
attr(x, "name")    # Returns "eval"
```

**Explanation**:
- `deparse(substitute(dataset))` captures the expression passed to `dataset` as a string.
- This defaults `name` to the object name (`"eval"` in the example) when not specified.
- If you want to override: `task_create(eval, name = "foo")` will set the name to `"foo"`.

content.text:
To achieve this, you can use **substitute()** and **deparse()** to capture the expression provided to thedatasetargument, then default the newnameargument to that value usingmissing(). Because you cant usesubstitute()directly on an argument **after** the function has been called, the common idiom is to setnametosubstitute(dataset)whennameis missing.

Heres how to do it:

```r
task_create <- function(
  dataset,
  name,
  dir = inspect_log_dir()
) {
  if (missing(name)) {
    name <- deparse(substitute(dataset))
  }
  check_dataset(dataset)

  dataset$id <- seq_len(nrow(dataset))

  res <-
    structure(
      dataset,
      class = c("task", class(tibble::new_tibble(list())))
    )

  attr(res, "dir") <- dir
  attr(res, "name") <- name # Add name attribute

  res
}
```

Now you get:

```r
eval <- tibble::tibble(a = 1:3)
x <- task_create(dataset = eval)
attr(x, "name")
# [1] "eval"

y <- task_create(dataset = eval, name = "custom_name")
attr(y, "name")
# [1] "custom_name"
```

**Note:** This will capture the expression supplied todataset, so eventask_create(dataset = some_fun())will store"some_fun()"as the name by default. If that's not desired, additional parsing may be needed.

messages.content: How do I jitter points with ggplot2 only with respect to the x axis, leaving the y values unchanged?

content.text:
To jitter points **only along the x axis** in `ggplot2`, use the `position_jitter()` function with the `width` argument nonzero (for x) and `height = 0` (so y does not jitter). Here's how you do it:

```r
ggplot(data, aes(x, y)) +
  geom_point(position = position_jitter(width = 0.2, height = 0))
```

- `width` sets the amount of x jitter; try values like 0.1 or 0.2 (adjust as needed).
- `height = 0` disables jitter on y.

**Example:**

```r
library(ggplot2)

ggplot(mtcars, aes(factor(cyl), mpg)) +
  geom_point(position = position_jitter(width = 0.2, height = 0))
```

**Tip:**  
You can also use `geom_jitter()` with `width` and `height`:

```r
ggplot(mtcars, aes(factor(cyl), mpg)) +
  geom_jitter(width = 0.2, height = 0)
```

Both approaches are equivalent for your purpose!

messages.content: How do I jitter points with ggplot2 only with respect to the x axis, leaving the y values unchanged?

content.text:
If you want to **jitter** points in ggplot2 only **along the x-axis** (keeping the y values fixed), you can use the `position_jitter()` or `position_jitterdodge()` with `width` set and `height = 0`. This applies jitter only to the x values.

### Example

Suppose you have data like:

```r
library(ggplot2)
set.seed(1)
df <- data.frame(
  x = factor(rep(letters[1:3], each=10)),
  y = rnorm(30)
)
```

Plot boxes (or whatever) and jitter points **only along x**:

```r
ggplot(df, aes(x = x, y = y)) +
  geom_point(
    position = position_jitter(width = 0.2, height = 0)
  )
```

- `width` controls the amount of jitter in the x direction.
- `height = 0` ensures **no jitter in the y direction**.

### Equivalent using `geom_jitter()`

Alternatively, `geom_jitter()` is a shortcut for `geom_point(position = position_jitter(...))`:

```r
ggplot(df, aes(x = x, y = y)) +
  geom_jitter(width = 0.2, height = 0)
```

---

**Summary:**  
To jitter only along x in ggplot2, set `width` to a nonzero value and `height = 0` in either `geom_jitter()` or `geom_point(position = position_jitter(...))`.

If you want to **jitter** points in ggplot2 only **along the x-axis** (keeping the y values fixed), you can use the `position_jitter()` or `position_jitterdodge()` with `width` set and `height = 0`. This applies jitter only to the x values.

### Example

Suppose you have data like:

```r
library(ggplot2)

  x = factor(rep(letters[1:3], each=10)),
  y = rnorm(30)
```

```r

  geom_point(
    position = position_jitter(width = 0.2, height = 0)
  )
```

- `width` controls the amount of jitter in the x direction.
- `height = 0` ensures **no jitter in the y direction**.

### Equivalent using `geom_jitter()`

Alternatively, `geom_jitter()` is a shortcut for `geom_point(position = position_jitter(...))`:

```r
ggplot(df, aes(x = x, y = y)) +
  geom_jitter(width = 0.2, height = 0)
```

---

**Summary:**  
To jitter only along x in ggplot2, set `width` to a nonzero value and `height = 0` in either `geom_jitter()` or `geom_point(position = position_jitter(...))`.

```r
    position = position_jitter(width = 0.2, height = 0)
  )
```

- `width` controls the amount of jitter in the x direction.
- `height = 0` ensures **no jitter in the y direction**.

### Equivalent using `geom_jitter()`

Alternatively, `geom_jitter()` is a shortcut for `geom_point(position = position_jitter(...))`:

```r
ggplot(df, aes(x = x, y = y)) +
  geom_jitter(width = 0.2, height = 0)
```

---

**Summary:**  
To jitter only along x in ggplot2, set `width` to a nonzero value and `height = 0` in either `geom_jitter()` or `geom_point(position = position_jitter(...))`.

content.text:
You can jitter points **only along the x-axis** in `ggplot2` by using the `position_jitter()` function and setting only the `width` argument (and leaving `height = 0`), or by using `position_jitterx()`, which is available in `ggplot2` 3.4.0 and newer.

### Method 1: Using `position_jitter()` with `height = 0`
```r
ggplot(data, aes(x, y)) +
  geom_point(position = position_jitter(width = 0.2, height = 0))
```
- `width` controls the jitter along the **x axis**.
- `height = 0` ensures **no jitter on the y axis**.

---

### Method 2: Using `position_jitterx()` (ggplot2  3.4.0)
```r
ggplot(data, aes(x, y)) +
  geom_point(position = position_jitterx(width = 0.2))
```
- No need to specify height; jitter is **only on x**.

---

**Summary:**  
> **Jitter only on x axis:**  
> `geom_point(position = position_jitter(width = ..., height = 0))`  
> or  
> `geom_point(position = position_jitterx(width = ...))` (if your ggplot2 version supports it)

samples.input:
I have some code

```
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    name = deparse(substitute(dataset)),
    dir = eval_log_dir()
) {
...
}
```

I'd like the default name to be the symbol referring to the dataset, e.g. in

```
simple_addition <- tibble(
  input = c("What's 2+2?", "What's 2+3?"),
  target = c("4", "5")
)

tsk <- 
  task_create(
    dataset = simple_addition
  )
```

...the name would be "simple_addition". Instead, it's substituted to `structure(list(input = c("What's 2+2?", "What's 2+3?"), target = c("4", , "5"), id = 1:2), row.names = c(NA, -2L), class = c("tbl_df", , and "tbl", "data.frame"))`. How can I fix that?
samples.target: The `name` default is evaluated lazily, and something else results in `dataset` being evaluated before `name` is. `name` must be evaluated early in the function, e.g. using `force(name)`.

messages.content:
I have some code

```
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    name = deparse(substitute(dataset)),
    dir = eval_log_dir()
) {
...
}
```

I'd like the default name to be the symbol referring to the dataset, e.g. in

```
simple_addition <- tibble(
  input = c("What's 2+2?", "What's 2+3?"),
  target = c("4", "5")
)

tsk <- 
  task_create(
    dataset = simple_addition
  )
```

...the name would be "simple_addition". Instead, it's substituted to `structure(list(input = c("What's 2+2?", "What's 2+3?"), target = c("4", , "5"), id = 1:2), row.names = c(NA, -2L), class = c("tbl_df", , and "tbl", "data.frame"))`. How can I fix that?

content.text:
Great question! The behavior you're seeing is because the default argument for `name` is evaluated **after** `dataset` is evaluated, so `deparse(substitute(dataset))` still points to the value, not the symbol, when that default is applied.

**TL;DR:**  
To have the default for `name` be the variable's symbol (e.g., `"simple_addition"`), do **not** set `name = deparse(substitute(dataset))` in the function signature. Instead, set `name = NULL`, and then fill it in inside the function **body** like this:

```r
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    name = NULL,
    dir = eval_log_dir()
) {
    if (is.null(name)) {
        name <- deparse(substitute(dataset))
    }
    ...
}
```

---

### Why This Works

- `deparse(substitute(dataset))` must be evaluated **inside the function** and only after `dataset` has been bound to the argument.
- Default arguments in R are evaluated in the **parent environment**, sometimes leading to weird behaviors if you set default `name = deparse(substitute(dataset))` directly in the signature.

---

### Example

```r
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    name = NULL,
    dir = eval_log_dir()
) {
    if (is.null(name)) name <- deparse(substitute(dataset))
    print(name)
    # ...
}

library(tibble)
simple_addition <- tibble(
  input = c("What's 2+2?", "What's 2+3?"),
  target = c("4", "5")
)

task_create(simple_addition)
# [1] "simple_addition"
```

---

### Advanced: Handling Expressions

content.text:
You are very close! The issue is with the evaluation environment order in this case.

### The Problem

Using  
```r
name = deparse(substitute(dataset))
```
in the function signature, **if the user supplies an explicit argument for `name`** (even the default), R evaluates its right-hand side **after the dataset argument is bound**. Because of this, `substitute(dataset)` sees the *value* (the dataset), not the symbol (`simple_addition`).

### The Solution

You need to use **delayed evaluation** on the default for `name`, so `substitute(dataset)` captures the *symbol* passed by the user. 

#### How-to: Move the default inside the function body

Heres the best practice:

```r
task_create <- function(dataset, name, dir = eval_log_dir()) {
  if (missing(name)) {
    name <- deparse(substitute(dataset))
  }
  ...
}
```

#### Example

```r
task_create <- function(dataset, name, dir = eval_log_dir()) {
  if (missing(name)) {
    name <- deparse(substitute(dataset))
  }
  print(name)
}

simple_addition <- tibble(
  input = c("What's 2+2?", "What's 2+3?"),
  target = c("4", "5")
)

task_create(dataset = simple_addition)
# [1] "simple_addition"
```

---

### **Summary Table**

| Approach                                          | Result              |
|---------------------------------------------------|---------------------|
| `name = deparse(substitute(dataset))` in signature| **Wrong result**    |
| `if (missing(name)) name <- deparse(substitute(dataset))` in body | **Works**  |

---

### **Pro Tip**

This is a common R idiom for using argument symbols as default names/titles. Moving the default inside the function is the recommended way!

---

content.text:
Great question! The problem arises because when you write `name = deparse(substitute(dataset))` directly in the **function argument defaults**, the substitution happens at **function definition time**, not at call time. As a result, inside the function, `name` is already the evaluated default, rather than referencing the calling context.

To get the correct symbol, you need to move the default handling **inside the function body**. Here's how you can do it:

```r
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    name = NULL,
    dir = eval_log_dir()
) {
  if (is.null(name)) {
    name <- deparse(substitute(dataset))
  }
  ...
  # rest of your function
}
```

### How this works:

- `name` is set to `NULL` by default.
- If not provided by the user, inside the body, you assign `name` to `deparse(substitute(dataset))`.
- Now, when you call:

```r
tsk <- task_create(dataset = simple_addition)
```

`name` will be `"simple_addition"`.

---

#### Quick proof of concept

```r
foo <- function(x, name = NULL) {
  if (is.null(name)) name <- deparse(substitute(x))
  name
}

bar <- 10
foo(bar)
#> [1] "bar"
```

---

**Summary**:  
**Don't** use `deparse(substitute(...))` as a default argument if it references other arguments.  
**Do** set the default to `NULL`, then assign using it **inside** the function.

model_graded_qa(scorer_chat = sonnet_3_7.explanation:
I need to evaluate whether the submission correctly identifies that the issue is related to using `NS(id)` instead of `session$ns` in the server function of Shiny modules.

The submission clearly identifies the core problem: using `NS(id)` in the server function creates a new namespace function that doesn't properly maintain the hierarchical relationship with parent modules. The submission correctly explains that:

1. `NS(id)` should only be used in UI functions
2. `session$ns` should be used in server functions
3. The key fix is to replace `ns <- NS(id)` with `ns <- session$ns` in the innerServer function

The submission provides a working solution that matches the criterion's explanation. It emphasizes the importance of namespace consistency between UI and server components, explaining that mismatched namespaces lead to the observed behavior where the UI shows but outputs don't render.

The submission also includes helpful code with comments showing where the changes should be made, and explains the key principle that will prevent similar issues in the future.

GRADE: C

model_graded_qa(scorer_chat = sonnet_3_7.explanation:
I need to evaluate whether the submission correctly identifies and resolves the issue with namespaces in nested Shiny modules.

The submission correctly identifies the core namespace problem in the code:
1. It points out that the outer module is calling inner modules with direct IDs (`innerServer("inner1")`) but the UI is using namespaced IDs (`inner_UI(ns("inner1"))`)
2. It correctly explains that this mismatch causes the server logic to use incorrect namespaces
3. It provides the correct solution of using `innerServer(ns("inner1"))` in the outer server function
4. It also recommends using `session$ns` inside moduleServer instead of creating a new namespace with `NS(id)`

The submission's explanation aligns perfectly with the criterion, which specifically mentions that `NS(id)` creates a new namespace function that doesn't maintain the correct hierarchical relationship with parent modules, while `session$ns` ensures properly-qualified namespaces.

The solution provided in the submission would correctly fix the issue with the dynamically generated UI elements not displaying properly.

GRADE: C

samples.input:
I have an R package that depends on a package called, lets say, spatialstuff (This is how it is defined in its DESCRIPTIONS). However it is found in an org and the repo name is different, eg org/spatial-Stuff (i have no control over this name!).

My package in its `DESCRIPTION` file has the following lines

```
Imports:
 spatialstuff
Remotes:
 org/spatial-Stuff
```

However the `pkgdown.yaml` workflow that is run upon pushes (created from `usethis::use_pkgdown_github_pages()`) errors with the following message.

Can someone explain if this is user error or some other error? Thanks

```
! error in pak subprocess
Caused by error:
! Could not solve package dependencies:
deps::.: Can't install dependency spatialstuff
* spatialstuff: Can't find package called spatialstuff.
* local::.: Can't install dependency spatialstuff
* any::sessioninfo: dependency conflict
* any::pkgdown: dependency conflict
```
samples.target: The user needs to specify the package name explicitly in the Remotes `DESCRIPTION` field using a `<package>=` prefix, e.g. `spatialstuff=org/spatial-Stuff`.

messages.content:
I have an R package that depends on a package called, lets say, spatialstuff (This is how it is defined in its DESCRIPTIONS). However it is found in an org and the repo name is different, eg org/spatial-Stuff (i have no control over this name!).

My package in its `DESCRIPTION` file has the following lines

```
Imports:
 spatialstuff
Remotes:
 org/spatial-Stuff
```

However the `pkgdown.yaml` workflow that is run upon pushes (created from `usethis::use_pkgdown_github_pages()`) errors with the following message.

Can someone explain if this is user error or some other error? Thanks

```
! error in pak subprocess
Caused by error:
! Could not solve package dependencies:
deps::.: Can't install dependency spatialstuff
* spatialstuff: Can't find package called spatialstuff.
* local::.: Can't install dependency spatialstuff
* any::sessioninfo: dependency conflict
* any::pkgdown: dependency conflict
```

content.text:
You are running into a **case sensitivity** and **repository naming** issue with how R resolves package dependencies when installing from GitHub.

### What's Happening?

- R package dependencies (i.e., names listed in `Imports:`) **must match the `Package:` field in the dependency's `DESCRIPTION` file**the _case_ matters (e.g., `spatialstuff` vs `SpatialStuff`).
- The `Remotes:` entry in your `DESCRIPTION` tells R/pak/devtools to look for the package on GitHub at `org/spatial-Stuff`.
- `pak` is seeing an `Imports: spatialstuff` and trying to find a CRAN package called `spatialstuff` (lowercase), not finding it, and not making the connection to the GitHub repo because the package directory/repo is called `spatial-Stuff` (with a capital S and a hyphen).

### What should you check/fix?

1. **Check the actual package name in its DESCRIPTION**

   Clone or browse [https://github.com/org/spatial-Stuff](https://github.com/org/spatial-Stuff), and look at `spatial-Stuff/DESCRIPTION`. Find:

   ```
   Package: ????
   ```

   - If it says `Package: spatialstuff` (all lowercase, no dash): your `Imports` and code are correct.
   - If it says `Package: spatial-Stuff` (dash or uppercase): YOUR `Imports` **must exactly match** this, i.e., `Imports: spatial-Stuff`.

2. **Check your `Remotes` entry**

   `Remotes` tells R where to fetch a non-CRAN dependency. Your line is correct _if_ that's the location:
   ```
   Remotes:
     org/spatial-Stuff
   ```

3. **Be aware of case/dash mismatches**

   R is case-sensitive for package names. Pak/devtools will try to match your `Imports` (`spatialstuff`) with the `Package:` field from the GitHub repo.

   - If these do not match _exactly_ (case- and dash-wise), installation fails and you get "Can't find package called spatialstuff".

### Possible Scenarios

#### 1. **DESCRIPTION mismatch**

If upstream's `DESCRIPTION` says:
```
Package: spatial-Stuff
```
and you have
```
Imports: spatialstuff
```
**this will fail**!

**Solution:**  
Adapt your `Imports` to match _exactly_ the name in `DESCRIPTION`:

```
Imports: spatial-Stuff
```

Or, ideally, fix upstream to standardize (if possible).

#### 2. **CRAN lookup confusion**
If you wrote `Imports: spatialstuff` and did not specify `Remotes`, R will try CRAN only. But you have a `Remotes` line, so it should look at both places. If it still fails, the names probably do not match.

#### 3. **Other conflicts**
If spatialstuff itself (or another dependency) fails to install due to a conflicting dependency (e.g. versions), you might also get a similar error, but from your error message it's a direct name mismatch.

### **How to Fix**

**Action items:**

- Go to: https://github.com/org/spatial-Stuff/blob/main/DESCRIPTION
- Find the `Package:` value.
- Make sure your `Imports:` and any code referring to that package use **exactly** that spelling/case/punctuation.

**Example:**

If their DESCRIPTION says:
```
Package: spatial-Stuff
```
Your DESCRIPTION must say:
```yaml
Imports:
  spatial-Stuff
Remotes:
  org/spatial-Stuff
```

**If it's `spatialstuff`:**
```yaml
Imports:
  spatialstuff
Remotes:
  org/spatial-Stuff
```

---

### **Summary Table**

| `Package:` in dependency DESCRIPTION | Your `Imports:`   | Your `Remotes:`                |
|--------------------------------------|-------------------|-------------------------------|
| `spatial-Stuff`                      | spatial-Stuff     | org/spatial-Stuff             |
| `spatialstuff`                       | spatialstuff      | org/spatial-Stuff             |

- They **must all match** (except for the repo name, which is just the GitHub path).

---

## **References**

- [R package DESCRIPTION file: Remotes field](https://r-pkgs.org/description.html#remotes)
- [Hadley Wickham: R is case sensitive for package names](https://github.com/r-lib/remotes/issues/246)
- [CRAN Policy](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/policies.html): "Package names must consist of only uppercase and lowercase letters and numbers, and must start with a letter, not a number."

---

## **TL;DR**

- Make sure the package name in your `Imports:` and `Remotes:` matches **exactly** the `Package:` field in the dependency's DESCRIPTION file (case and punctuation included).
- R's package installation machinery is **case sensitive** and will not map between `spatialstuff` and `spatial-Stuff`.

Let me know if you need help checking the actual DESCRIPTION file or adapting your YAML!

content.text:
Great, let's break down the issue step by step:

---

### **1. What are the relevant files/settings?**

- DESCRIPTION
  ```plain
  Imports:
    spatialstuff
  Remotes:
    org/spatial-Stuff
  ```
- Your **dependency is called `spatialstuff` in R** (e.g., the package loads with `library(spatialstuff)`), but its **GitHub repo is `org/spatial-Stuff`**.

---

### **2. How does R (and install tools) resolve this?**

- The **Remotes** field tells R (and tools like `pak` and `devtools`) where to get the package `spatialstuff` **if it isn't on CRAN**.
- **Remotes** are only consulted _if_ the package manager can't find a matching package on CRAN/BioC/etc.

- The repo can have a different name than the R package **as long as the `.Rproj` and `DESCRIPTION` inside the repo say `Package: spatialstuff`**.

  > For example, on GitHub: `org/spatial-Stuff` could contain a `DESCRIPTION` file `Package: spatialstuff`.

---

### **3. What does the error mean?**

The key lines:
```
Can't install dependency spatialstuff
* spatialstuff: Can't find package called spatialstuff.
```
mean that the package resolver (`pak` in this case) **can't find a package called `spatialstuff`**.

---

### **4. Causes of this issue**

#### **A. Mismatch between package name and DESCRIPTION**

**If the `DESCRIPTION` inside `org/spatial-Stuff` does _not_ say `Package: spatialstuff`, but maybe `spatial-Stuff`**, then R will not recognize it as `spatialstuff`.

- R looks for the package name inside the `DESCRIPTION` file, not the repo name.
- The name must **match exactly** (case-sensitive, no hyphens vs underscores).

#### **B. Typos or case mismatches**

- If you say `Imports: spatialstuff` but the package is actually called `spatial-Stuff`, it won't resolve.

---

### **5. How to debug**

#### **a. Check the DESCRIPTION of `org/spatial-Stuff`**

- On GitHub, go to `org/spatial-Stuff/DESCRIPTION`.
- Confirm what exactly the `Package:` line says **(including case! R is case sensitive)**.

#### **b. Repo does not matter; only package name in DESCRIPTION matters**

#### **c. Make sure DESCRIPTION is up to date in your dependency repo**

---

### **6. Standard workaround if you cannot change the dependency**

- **You cannot control the upstream repo**? You have to match whatever the package itself says.
- So **change your DESCRIPTION** to match their package name.
  - E.g., if their `Package:` line is `spatial-Stuff`, _not_ `spatialstuff`, then use:
    ```
    Imports:
      spatial-Stuff
    Remotes:
      org/spatial-Stuff
    ```
  - and load with `library("spatial-Stuff")` in your code!

---

### **7. Summary Table**

| Repo Name             | Package Name in DESCRIPTION | What to Import? | What to put in Remotes?   |
|-----------------------|----------------------------|-----------------|---------------------------|
| org/spatial-Stuff     | spatialstuff               | spatialstuff    | org/spatial-Stuff         |
| org/spatial-Stuff     | spatial-Stuff              | spatial-Stuff   | org/spatial-Stuff         |

---

### **8. Further Reading**

- [R Packages: DESCRIPTION fields](https://r-pkgs.org/description.html#remotes)
- [R Package Development: Name vs Repo](https://r-pkgs.org/name.html)

---

## **Bottom Line**

> **The name in your `Imports:` MUST match the `Package:` field in the dependencys DESCRIPTION file, regardless of the GitHub repo name.**

- **If they differ, you'll get these resolution errors.**
- **Adjust your DESCRIPTION accordingly.**

---

### **Action Plan**

1. **Look up the `Package:` field in `org/spatial-Stuff`'s DESCRIPTION**.
2. **Make your `Imports:` and `Remotes:` match* the package name.**
3. **Try again.**

If you can't control the upstream and they use an odd package name, you must use their choice.

---

## **Example Fix**

Suppose `org/spatial-Stuff/DESCRIPTION` says:

```plain
Package: spatial-Stuff
```

Then use:

```plain
Imports:
  spatial-Stuff
Remotes:
  org/spatial-Stuff
```

Not `spatialstuff`!

---
